system.base.Wet_database

class

Static Methods

cached_query(sql_cmd : String, ?args : Array<Dynamic>, ?dirty_pages : List<String>) : Wet_cached_result

parameters
dirty_pages This is list of all the TABLES that are used in this query. to ensure that the garbage collector only clears caches that are involved in subsquent writes.
see
query()
TODO GARBAGE COLLECTION!
TODO This could impliment an auto function to automatically cache functions that take more than N uSeconds to complete.
TODO A function to FORCE an overwrite on collision might be useful.
Does a cached SQL query - caching to the local file store. Tracing is not used here. The filename is generated from a simple hash based on the SQL command (has to be a SELECT, other things dirty the cache). The data is seralised and stored in the File together with the full SQL string to ensure collisions do not return the wrong info!

close() : Void

get_instance(?dbtype : String, ?host : String, ?port : Int, ?socket : String, ?user : String, ?pass : String, ?database : String, ?trase : Bool) : Wet_database

Constructor creates a connection to a database The SQlite factory is special in that it operates on a FILE so the HOST parameter is the filename (database name) but can be an absolute path too. If just a filename is supplied, SQlite will work on a the magic system path DATASTORE which is in your application folder and should be read/writable by Apache etc. but protected from World access. If you supply a path, that will be used instead (this is the recommended method) you can put the database out of reach. Giving TRUE to the trace element gets the syste to output connection information.
